awd_titl_txt: Center for Undergraduate Research in Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
The Center for Undergraduate Research in Mathematics (CURM) promotes academic year undergraduate research in mathematics and statistics based upon a model consisting of (a) training faculty members to mentor students in research, (b) engaging 2-5 students and a faculty mentor in research during the academic year at their own institution, (c) preparing students to succeed in graduate studies, and (d) advising faculty members on how to maintain consistent undergraduate research including finding resources for other funding sources. Each year, CURM will administer mini-grants to about 54 undergraduate students working in 16 groups during the academic year at various institutions across the U.S, and will provide a workshop for faculty mentor training and spring conference events for students to present their research. In past years, CURM has primarily reached four-year or comprehensive institutions. The center is now expanding its reach by (a) creating regional cross-institutional collaborations, with an emphasis on community colleges; (b) promoting regional mathematical community by integrating CURM into regional mathematical structures and outreach activities; and (c) incubating research activity at teaching-focused institutions through connections to student research. 

The CURM participants will perform research in various areas of mathematics. Undergraduate students will conduct research in mathematics, prepare and present conference talks, and write and publish research papers related to this research. Faculty will revitalize their research programs and connect their work to their local mathematical community. Engaging students in research provides these faculty members with an opportunity to align their research interests with the goals of their institutions. This can be particularly important for women and other underrepresented groups whose work is known to be undervalued and are who are therefore more likely to work at an institution whose research emphasis is not matched with their research talents. By adding institutional partnerships, CURM stands to spread its mentoring expertise to PhD-granting institutions where mentoring may not be a priority, and its connections to a well-established network for community colleges where undergraduate research in mathematics has not yet taken hold. The new effort to cultivate regional strengths through CURM stands to contribute to robust intellectual communities in more isolated parts of the country.

por.por_cntn:
The Center for Undergraduate Research in Mathematics (CURM) promotes academic year undergraduate research in mathematics and statistics based upon a model consisting of (a) training faculty members to mentor students in research, (b) engaging small groups of students and a faculty mentor in research during the academic year at their own institution, (c) preparing students to succeed in future mathematical studies, and (d) advising faculty members on how to maintain consistent undergraduate research programs, including finding resources for other funding sources.

Building on more than a decade of experience, this award expanded CURM's vision by (a) creating regional cross-institutional collaborations, with an emphasis on community colleges; (b) promoting regional mathematical community by integrating CURM into regional mathematical structures and outreach activities; and (c) incubating research activity at teaching-focused institutions through connections to student research.

This funding period supported 82 faculty leading research groups totaling more than 250 student participants at institutions across 33 states, including 9 Historically Black Colleges and Universities (11%), 15 Hispanic Serving Institutions (18%), 2 Native Serving Institutions (2%), 2 Women's Colleges (2%), and 5 community or 2-year colleges (6%). Many of the participating professors and their institutions continue to support and conduct undergraduate research based on the CURM program, with several institutions expanding the model beyond mathematics.

All student researchers gave presentations in local mathematics conferences, and completed a total of more than 70 research papers with at least 24 submitted for publication. Research topics included areasof theoretical mathematics, including graph theory, number theory, complex analysis, and differential equations, as well as projects with a broad array of applications, including oceanography, epidemiology, astronomy, imaging, environmental science, sports, and education.  

Based on pre- and post-CURM experience surveys of each of the five cohorts, we see significant results for faculty and student participants. Faculty saw increases of time spent doing and discussing research,and many faculty saw an increase in the level of support and mentorship they received from colleagues. Students saw increases across in research skills, sense of belonging, confidence in abilities, mathematical skills, and access to support from faculty, with high statistically significance. Moreover, the CURM experience closed initial gender and racial and ethnic disparities, with women and students of color scoring lower than their counterparts in the pre-test, but then increasing to the same level (women) or beyond (students of color) in the post-test, and with students of color seeing increases in more areas. First generation students, whose pre-tests were higher than their counterparts, also showed very strong outcomes on the post-test where they again surpassed their counterparts. In short, CURM continues to have a significant impact on students studying mathematics throughout the US, and with a stronger impact on students from groups that have been marginalized in mathematics.
